questions.question_text:
Your company has a main office in Dallas.
The company has a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
Currently, the default audio conferencing bridge is set to a phone number that has a Miami area code.
In the Microsoft Teams admin center, you get a number in the Dallas area code.
You need to assign the new Dallas number as the default audio conferencing bridge.
What should you configure in the Microsoft Teams admin center?

choices.A: Assign a dial-out policy to the user.
choices.E: Remove Communications Credits from the user.
choices.D: Assign a domestic-only calling plan to the user.
choices.C: Assign a tenant dial plan to the user.
choices.B: Disable Enterprise Voice for the user.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Despite the confusing name, it's not a license. It's a feature/config in TAC>Users>Voice.

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
under user - Audio Conferencing -edit

Selected Answer: A
"A" is right. You can change/set the dial-out restriction in the Audio Conferencing settings of the user or use PowerShell (Grant-CsDialoutPolicy) on user level.

questions.question_text:
You need to prevent a specific user from calling international phone numbers from within a Microsoft Teams meeting.
What should you do?

HOTSPOT -
You have a dial plan named DP1.
You need to assign DP1 to a new Microsoft Teams user named User1. You must verify that the appropriate dial plan and the associated normalization rules are assigned to User1.
How should you complete the PowerShell script? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: Correct! The answers are Grant-CsTenantDialPlan and Get-CsEffectiveTenantDialPlan.

I agree! As it says: "You must verify that the appropriate dial plan and the associated normalization rules are assigned" the "GET-" command should to the trick.

I doesn't say: "You have to check if the normalization of number XXX is correct". So "TEST- "is wrong here.

discussion.content:
My two cents on this:
First part Grant-CsTenantDialPlan looks correct.
Second part I think Get-CsEffectiveTenantDialPlan should be the answer.

There is no number to test in the second part. 

MS documentation says:
"The Get-CsEffectiveTenantDialPlan cmdlet returns information about the effective tenant dial plan in an organization. The returned effective Tenant Dial Plan contains the EffectiveTenantDialPlanName and the Normalization rules that are effective for the user while using the EnterpriseVoice features."

The information should be enough to confirm that it has been applied to the user.

Any thoughts?

Grant-CSTenantDialPlan
Get-CwEffectiveTenantDialPlan

to assign Assign custom dial plan to user1 should use 
Grant-CsTenantDialPlan -Identity user1@contoso.com -PolicyName DP1
To Verify assigned dial plan with associated normalization should use 
Get-CsEffectiveTenantDialPlan -Identity

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer.

B

Buy an Office 365 E5 or Microsoft 365 Enterprise E5 plan and add a PSTN connectivity option.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/training/modules/plan-teams-phone-system/3-determine-license-requirements

Oh c'mon. That is soooo wrong. It is "B". Phone System license is not available for E3. That here is a example of a question set, that was Copy & Paste on another learning platform which also was the wrong answer E3. :D

Selected Answer: B
To achieve this Teams license and Phone System license are required. Both are provided only in E5 (both Office and Microsoft 365 products). In E3 versions, there is no phone system license, and would have to be assigned separately.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/licensing-service-plan-reference

questions.question_text:
You need to provide Microsoft Teams users with the ability to perform PSTN calling through a Session Border Controller (SBC).
Which licenses can you assign to achieve the goal?

choices.F: Microsoft 365 Domestic and International Calling Plan

discussion.content:

Please note Virtual user license is now called Teams Phone Resource Account license

virtual user/ resource account for cq and aa

"B" + "C" seems correct. A ressource account would get the "virtual user" license and if it's calling plan, the ressource account needs coverage of costs for dialing out to a external numbers.

B and C are correct.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You plan to deploy auto attendants and call queues.
The support desk requires that its auto attendant be able to forward calls after hours to local mobile phone numbers.
You need to identify which licenses to assign to auto-attendant. The solution must minimize costs.
Which two licenses should you identify? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
